pullRequest.body:
# Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) Matrix and DFT of a (finite) sequence 
  
 This file defines the `dft` opertaion on a sequence (also a vecotr) and the DFT operation matrix 
  
 ## Main definitions 
  
  - `dft v`: given a sequence (v : (Fin n) → ℂ) we can transform it into a sequence (V : (Fin n) →ℂ) 
  such that 
  $$V [p] = ∑_{k = 0}^{N - 1} e^{-j*2πkp/n} v [k]$$ 
  - `idft V` : given a sequence (V : (Fin n) → ℂ) we can transform it into a sequence 
  (v : (Fin n) → ℂ) 
 such that 
 $$v [k] = \frac{1}{N}∑_{p = 0}^{n - 1} e^{j*2πkp/N} v [p]$$ 
 - `dftMatrix n` : the dft matrix of dimensions $n \times n$ with the `k, p` entry equal to 
 $$Wₙ[k, p] = e^{-j2πkp/n}$$ 
 - `(dftMatrix n)⁻¹` : the idft matrix of dimensions $n \times n$ with the `k, p` entry equal to 
 $$Wₙ[k, p] = (1/N) e^{j2πkp/n}$$ 
  
  
 ## Main results 
  
 - `dft v = (dftMatrix n) v` : the dft operation on a sequence is the same as the dft matrix applied to the vector 
 - `idft V = (dftMatrix n)⁻¹ V` : the idft operation on a sequence is the same as the idft matrix applied to the vector 
 - `dft (idft v) = dft ( idft v) = v` the dft and idft operations are inverses 
 - `Wₙ = vandermonde (w)` : the dft matrix is vandermonde with `w` being the first row of the dft matrix 
 - `circulant t = (dftMatrix n)⁻¹ ⬝ diagonal (dft t) ⬝ (dftMatrix n)` : a circulant matrix is diagonalizable by the dft and idft matrix pair.


---

nodes.body: sorry, a lot of style and code nits!

```suggestion
Copyright (c) 2023 Mohanad Ahmed. All rights reserved.
```

```suggestion
This file defines the `dft` opertaion on a sequence (also a vector) and the DFT operation matrix
```

I'd really rather you expand out DFT and IDFT in the docstrings for most of the time. It doesn't read very well this way.

Why should we only use `\C`? This can plausbily be defined for anything with a primitive root of unity, and I think tying it into the `IsPrimitiveRoot` stuff will make some of your results a lot easier to prove.

```suggestion
 $$ V [p] = ∑_{k = 0}^{N - 1} e^{-i*2πkp/n} v [k] $$
```

And similar below.

```suggestion
 - `dft v`: The discrete fourier transform of `v` is given by:
 $$ V[p] = \sum_{k=0}^{N-1]} \zeta^k v(k) $$
```

and again similar below
is that character at the start a ¼?
No it was supposed to be \frac
I don't think this is like mathlib naming conventions at all

Yes but it is the standard notation for the DFT matrix see for example (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DFT_matrix) or (https://www.math.uwaterloo.ca/~hwolkowi/matrixcookbook.pdf). The DFT  has extensive applications in signal processing where I think this notation prevails
sure, but standard for mathlib is to name it something like `dft_matrix` or the like (I'm not sure with the lean4 conventions) - we can note the normal maths names elsewhere

```suggestion
- `Wₙ = vandermonde w` : the dft matrix is vandermonde with `w` being the first row of the dft
```

```suggestion
- `dft (idft v) = dft (idft v) = v` the dft and idft operations are inverses
```
the spacing is weird elsewhere too

```suggestion
noncomputable def dft (v : (Fin n) → ℂ) : Fin n → ℂ :=
```
I don't see why you require `NeZero`, I know mathematically it doesn't matter but it will make things more annoying to use at the point of use
please remove all random commented code unless you want us to take a look at it!

```suggestion
lemma cexp_sub_ne_one {m : ℕ} (k p : Fin m) (h : k ≠ p) :
```

You definitely don't need `NeZero m`; you can do the case split early in your proof, get an immediate contradiction from `k : Fin 0` and then prove everything as is.

I also think this is an insanely long result for this proof; something of this form should either be https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/RootsOfUnity/Complex.html or in the general RootsOfUnity file, and again making the whole wheel for yourself again probably wasted you a lot of time
OK I implemented the case split on zero suggestion
shouldn't be here; also may it be more profitable to use some other `mod` like `Int.fmod` or `%`?

```suggestion
/-- The IDFT operation and IDFT matrix applied to sequence/vector are the same -/
```

I think you've gone overboard on some docstrings and not enough on more complicated ones, or the ones that set up the definitions. Some theorems are fine without docstrings.
This could be stated in terms of `Function.Right/LeftInverse`, I think
Probably good to have the `Bijective` results, too
I'm fairly sure this exists somewhere in https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Logic/Equiv/Fin.html
mathlib style is for spacing here, iot does make things a lot more readable, also we don't include brackets unless necessary / helps readability (e.g. if the priorities imply it but it's not obvious)

```suggestion
    Complex.exp ((2 * π * I) * (a * (shiftk_equiv b x) / n) := by
```
you don't need nezero in either this nor the theorem just below
